segments.text: I basically did not trust them.
I mean, I was really early on was convinced we were in a guerrilla conflict.
From January to, I want to say, April, I was breaking in at the Third Surge in Bien Hoa.
And then they decided that they would really make it mobile.
And there was going to be a big operation in the highlands up near Pleiku.
And they were going to take the hospital on the road.
And some brilliant person decided that they could not take the fragile women along.
So they played fruit basket turnover with every nurse corps officer in the entire command in MACV.
And they brought all the men nurses in to the third search, and they shipped all of us women out to replace them.
And I got sent down to the third field in Saigon, which might have well have been Walter Reed.
It was the same problem again.
And when I reported in, in my fatigues, who was the brand new chief nurse sitting at the desk but brand new Lieutenant Colonel Kitty Betts.
And her first words to me were, well, Lieutenant Hart, you didn't last out in the field very long, did you?
And I said, no, ma'am.
But I won't be here long either, ma'am.
And she said, you know, you can't wear that outfit here.
This is a station hospital.
You've got to have duty whites.
I said, man, my orders do not stipulate duty whites, and I don't have them with me.
I'll have to wear my fatigues.
She said, no, you won't.
You can wear your class B greens.
So you know that little whack outfit, that little green and white polyester thing with the short sleeves and the black shoes?
That's what I wore in Saigon on the wards on duty.

and I arrived my first that night for night shift I mean so much for orientation now they yak on and on about how we have to take these little children under our wings and teach them everything we know about our environment for six weeks before we make them responsible for anything and those days we just walked in and said hi I'm the new nurse where's the where do you keep the you know
And I arrived, and there were two medics there, kind of wondering if a nurse was going to show up.
What it was is the third field had been the American school in Saigon before the balloon went up and the war got big, and they moved all the embassy dependents out.
And it was built like a school, and this was a four-classroom, single-story wing, a little lanai sort of affair, with a covered porch out in front of it.
And those four classrooms were my four wards, and they each had about ten beds in them.
Again, three of them were surgical wards, and the fourth one in the back was the clap ward.
And all the guys with epididymitis and swollen scrotums and stuff like that would go in and lob the ice bags under the sheet.
Chunk, you know, chunk.
You don't look.
You just throw.
You can arrange it yourself.
but give out lots and lots of penicillin, streptomycin, chloramycin.
Antibiotic rounds were a biggie.
I was just counting my blessings I didn't get sent over to the gymnasium where they had the malaria patients in triple bunks.
There were like 80, 120 of them at a time in the gymnasium in these bunks.
My roommate was a medical nurse and worked in the gymnasium.
Ugh, bad.
And I wasn't in the neuro floor either, where all the guys with the gunshot wounds to the head were busy expiring.
I was no fun.
Interestingly enough, I met a nurse there who was a full-blooded Navajo Indian.
Now, A, you don't see very many women Navajos off the reservation in the first place.
B, very doggone few of them end up as college graduates with a profession.
And C, they don't leave New Mexico and Arizona, even when they have.
And Annie Yazzie, for some reason, ended up in the Army Nurse Corps and assigned to Vietnam.
She had a
All her black hair pulled into a single braid that she could sit on, and she coiled it up, smacked her nurse corps hat on.
You want to talk about somebody who had culture shock with that, she would be worth a book all by herself.
Real quiet, and nobody got to know her very well.
I don't think I ever saw her smile.
But from what I know about Navajos, that may not have meant what it would have meant for me.
She worked on the neural floor.
Anyway, so.

About two months later, after they had had to court-martial two of the male nurses, and they had had terrible disciplinary problems with the drinking and the gambling and the carousing that was going on, the third search just went to sea, bad, with no civilizing influence.
The CO put his foot down and said, I want my troops back.
And they hauled us all back in, except a couple of gals refused to come back.
They were mad, and they were not submitting to it if they weren't directly ordered.
But most of us went back, and all those other guys get sent, who we never saw, so they were just, you know, Figman's ideas, went back to where they were supposed to be.
And in that two months in Saigon, it was brought home to me real fast that this was a guerrilla operation and you couldn't trust anybody.
I mean, it was daily stories of, you know, my own medics on night shift were out shopping one morning when they got off duty and somebody threw a grenade in their little pedicab, and
One of them picked it up and threw it back out, and there were about 15 people killed and hurt just on the street.
And he was doing split-second thinking.
He didn't think about where he threw it.
He just thought about getting it out from under his own feet.
And he was weird for a week after that.
So I never wanted to win the hearts and minds of people.
I didn't really want to get to know them because I didn't trust them, just from ground zero.
Not that I blamed them for it.
I just accepted it as a fact of life, like a snake handler who respects their abilities.
Or a tiger tamer, you know.
When it came time for you to leave, how did you feel about it?
How did you cope with your feelings?
I was glad to leave.
It was a 12-month tour, and I came in as a replacement mid-tour.
One of the gals who went over with the original batch with the third search was just diagnosed as being pregnant and was sent back six months into the tour, and I was sent to replace her.
So I went through three crews in my 18 months.
The people who were there for six months after I got there then left, and the new crew came in.
I spent most of the year with them, and then because of the extension,
I was working with virtually strangers when I got ready to leave.
So I didn't have any ties to break with my coworkers because they had left me.
This picture shows it pretty well because this was when we set up in Dong Tam.
And those of us who had been with the unit in Bien Hoa were all wearing Third Surge patches.
And when we set up in Dong Tam, there's only two of us left with that patch on.
What happened to the picture?
No, mislighted.
Well, anyway, these were our third surge patches.
Oh, here we go.
You see?
There's only two of us left with that patch on.
The others, these kids, I don't even remember their names.
I served with them for about two months.
And during that two months, we packed up and we moved, what, 150 kilometers south and reset up, and we set up an inflatable hospital.
That's the only picture I've got that shows the inflatable units.
Most of the time, we were in what were called Southeast Asia Hooches, which were basically looked like this.
At some point in time, we plasticed over the windows and put in single-unit window air conditioners.
These were the litter racks in pre-op.
This is when they carried the litters in off the helicopter, just plopped them right on that.
The metal litter racks just were not cool, so the sergeants built those.
They were sturdier and stayed put when you were doing things like CPR.
But, I don't know, it had been 18 months.
I was six months a bride and had never really lived with my husband.
He'd been wounded twice.
I was really kind of interested in getting him out of there, too.
My dad had gone on home, and I was ready to go back and start on the next part of my life.
I was getting out of the Army.
In those days, you did.
You know, I was a wife.
I was going to have children.
I was going to wear white clothes and go to lunches and coffees and, you know, do all that good stuff like my mother had done before me.
Little did I know that social change was swirling around me as I even spoke.
I wasn't even planning to work.
What did you feel like when you returned?

I'd never seen so many things to buy and eat and you know you didn't have to to worry about you didn't have to look twice at the cab driver you know that kind of thing I just remember just being delighted tired jet lag kind of you came back on a 26-hour flight and then you changed air airports you know you had to take the shuttle bus down from Travis to the
San Francisco, whatever that airport is called.
And then we flew to Denver.
We got into Denver about 1 in the morning.
His folks were there to pick us up.
We got in the station wagon in the middle of the night and drove three hours south to his home in Lamar, Colorado.
And about, you know, 4 in the morning, I climbed into bed.
I mean, you don't have a lot of, let's examine our reactions.
You know, you get real, real...
I woke up about noon because I was convinced that I was being bombed.
And I scrambled up in this strange bedroom, in this strange bed.
I scrambled the headboard of the bed, and there's a window right over it, and there's this airplane coming right for me.
And I screamed.
And it just, I went, whoo, it was a crop duster.
And, of course, Lee had grown up with that stuff all his life, but I'd grown up on air bases, and when a plane was coming right for you, this was problems.
I wasn't used to people flying 20 feet off the deck for no good reason.
But then it was a matter of, I had no clothes.
What I had, I had left with my folks a year and a half before.
And it was half the country away.
I had to go shopping.
I had to get a few things.
I didn't really have any big reaction.
We left there and went and visited my folks briefly in Washington.
Then we drove down to

Fort Benning and got our quarters and then we left there and went up to Jody and Bob's wedding and then we went back to Fort Benning and of course we were living with people who had all just well at least the guys had just all come through the same thing and a lot of them were people we knew it was Benning was a big post everybody was there for the advanced course and most of them were first lieutenants moving into promotable for captain and so a lot of our same buddy group
was there either at the same time or came before we left.
Did you talk about Vietnam at all with these people?
With them, yes.
Do you think that helped you return the vice those who just got out and returned back to the Seminole?
It wasn't ever that hard on me.
I mean, bad things happen to people who are in hospitals.
That's never changed.
It was true when I was a student nurse at Maryview.
People had cancer.
People got hit by trucks.
You know, things happen.
We handle gunshot wounds every day at Scott and White.
Well, not every day, but it's not infrequent.
And so the how they got that way wasn't a big issue.
Now, for the guys who were cannon fodder, I guess it was a big issue.
Why did I get sent out there to get shot at?
But, uh...
The thing I absorbed from them over the next year was a terrible and bitter sense of having been sent off to do something and then sent back to be spit at.
That brings us to how do you feel about the protesters?
Vicious.
I have absolutely no use for them.
As an employer, I will not hire one if I know that's in their background, and I will find some other way to justify it, since I know I have an illegal leg to stand on.
Do you have any other thing you want to add or feel would be pertinent?
It hasn't ever been the same for me as it has for him.
When we were in Colorado and he was on degree completion, I was getting a degree too with my GI Bill.
I'm one of the few women veterans you'll ever meet who used the whole sucker up.
I got a bachelor's and all but one semester of a master's out of it.
I just considered it was something they owed me.
You know, I don't know if I'd have felt that way
if it hadn't been for the fact that it was not a patriotic, publicly supported war.
But I really felt like then it held me.
Not because I felt like I'd been under great hardships or, you know, because it hadn't been.
I lived good.
I ate A-rations, fresh lettuce, ice cream.
I mean, I was in a hospital for Pete's sake.
Now, granted, the outfits we wore left something to be desired in terms of fashion, but hey, they were comfy.

I had a Sears and Roebuck charge card and a catalog I was the shopping center of the entire Third Surge always had orders coming back and forth the APO 96227 that Sears and Roebuck knew that well we all dressed out of Sears and it was all on my charge card but the few of them that I have met since
And the most recent one is Karen Mundell.
This lady now has a PhD.
She also used up all her GI Bill.
And she's the director of the Women's Center at St. Luke's AMI in Denver, Colorado.
And she's a nationally known speaker at healthcare conferences.
And, you know, we became competent under those circumstances.

We were cut away from absolutely everything else that we had depended on in the past, and we did what we did, and we did it well, and we survived, and we became very cut and dry about how things are attacked, how things are approached, how problems are, the problem-solving process.
And I think that's the invisible link when we recognize each other because we have this very brusque,

attitude that you don't get in a real structured hospital environment where there's always bosses bosses bosses kind of thing we didn't have that you were the pre-op nurse in the middle of the night you were it until the others got themselves shagged out of their bags and you know brushed their teeth and got there to help you and decisions you made in that 10 minutes were critical it was

it was a real interesting way to spend a couple years of your youth very few of them stayed in the MERS corps a number of them rejoined I ran into a number of them eight years later when I rejoined and they'd all had breaks in service and had gone out and found that indeed the civilian world did have a tendency to be slow and corporate and all that kind of thing and then we joined the army and found out that in peacetime it did too
We were used to combat pace of this and these fixed.
Fix it.
And, you know, filling out three years in advance capital budget schedules and that kind of thing just wasn't our idea of how things were done.
But like I said before, the names change and you can't keep track of these people.
And so, you know, other than having, I ran into Karen at a conference just last year.
I don't know where any of these people are.
Thanks for your time.
Thanks for that interview.
You're welcome.
This has been an interview with Geraldine Ann Johnson, maiden name Hart.
She served in the Army Nurse Corps and was stationed at Vietnam from January 1966 to June 1967.
She is married to a retired Army Lieutenant Colonel Lee Leonard C. Johnson with two children.
She is presently the head nurse at Pediatrics located at Scott and White, Temple, Texas.
